commit.message:
drbd.rules: use drbdsetup udev command

Use the new drbdsetup command instead of drbdadm. Since the new command
always creates the same environement, we can also clean up a lot of the
legacy cruft around older utils version.

With this change, the compatibility for implicit volumes added in

ea8fec5632ae drbd udev: fix inconsistent inheritance of implicit volumes

is removed: all volumes will always use the extra /<vnr> links. This should
be fine, as all recent drbd-utils versions already had the equivalent
"udev-always-use-vnr" option enabled in the default configuration.

drbdsetup: add udev command

Add a new command to create environment descriptions for udev based on the
in-kernel description. This is a replacement for the drbadm "sh-udev" command,
which by comparison uses the drbdadm configuration.

This has a number of advantages:

* The udev configuration is always in sync with what is actually configured
  in the kernel: in the drbdadm configuration, a changed config file that was
  not fully applied would still result in updated udev links, even if those
  links are now wrong.
* There might be issues with parsing the drbdadm configuration: in this case,
  we could not generate any udev links: this is no longer an issue.
* A particular issue is the use of the hostname in configuration: because
  systemd-udev often starts before the hostname is configured and it uses
  ProtectHostname=, it oftentimes keeps the "generic" hostname, while DRBD
  is configured with the updated hostname. drbdadm then does not find the
  "correct" host in the configuration, generating no links at all.

configure.ac: Add an option to disable host udev version checks

In cross-compilation environment, the build host might have an outdated
udev or no udev at all. But the user may still want to build with the
enabled udev rule (for its udev-enabled target).

This patch adds a "--disable-udevchecks" option the disable build host
udev version check at configure-time and unconditionally install the
enabled udev rule. Without this new option, the behavior stays the same
(checks enabled).

Signed-off-by: Yoann Congal <yoann.congal@smile.fr>
Signed-off-by: Roland Kammerer <roland.kammerer@linbit.com>

scripts/snapshot-resync: Filter DRBD devices from LVM commands

If the primary node is up againg during resync, the script is called
on the still inconsistent secondary node and so LVM can't read the
DRBD devices.

With this fix DRBD devices are specially excluded, without the need
of a global_filter for LVM.

drbdsetup,v9: show TLS in connection status

A user might want to make sure that TLS is actually used. With this commit
this information is displayed in the output of drbdsetup status.

Note that we generally do not show such information (net_conf stuff) in the
status output: we do not even show the addresses for the connection. For TLS
we make an exception: if you enable TLS it's probably important, and having a
simple way to confirm the configuration will help users in their setup.

drbdadm: create-md: new options --effective-size, --diskful-peers

Allow to pass through --effective-size and --diskful-peers to create-md.
If --effective-size is set, but --diskful-peers is not explicitly set,
caclulate the list of node-ids of the diskful peers,
and pass it down to drbdmeta.

drbdmeta: create-md: new options --effective-size and --diskful-peers

Various peers may have backing devices of different sizes.
That can be hard to avoid with LVM and different PE sizes on the nodes,
or when connecting nodes with different types of backends (zvol on some,
LVM on other nodes).

If we start to use a DRBD volume on one of the nodes with a larger
backing device, we may be unable to connect the smaller backends later,
because that then would "truncate" the size of the now already
initialized volumes on the nodes with the larger backing devices.

The "correct" way would be to first fully connect the DRBD cluster,
so DRBD can to its initial handshake and sync and "agree" on the
maximum size that can be supported by all nodes in the cluster.

But we (LINSTOR) wants to start using (or initializing with mkfs) a new
volume without waiting for all peers to be fully connected.  And Linstor
has enough context information to know what that size will be.

We can initialize the "last agreed to" respectively "effective" size
when creating the DRBD meta data. Additionally, we need to flag
our diskful peers as "MDF_PEER_DEVICE_SEEN".

That way, during attach, DRBD will know that there are some other
nodes with backing devices, and know that it does NOT know their current
size, but see the persisted "effective" size as "last agreed" size,
and settle for that until the time it learns about the actual backing
device size of the peers once connected.
add missing include for recently added call to include_file()
fix typo in error message

events2: set may_promote:no promotion_score:0 while force-io-failure:yes

We had some reactor magic try to promote a node that was
"secondary --force"d before, and was still held open by old references.

Trying to promote in that state results in the error message
> State change failed: (-12) Device is held open by someone
In response to "drbdadm primary", that may be a bit "confusing" at first.

We should not report that state as "promotable".

Update scripts/drbd to fix "no such file" bug, which presented as follows:

Starting DRBD resources:/etc/init.d/drbd: line 148: /var/lib/linstor/loop_device_mapping: No such file or directory
[

Also, with requested comment modification per:
https://github.com/LINBIT/drbd-utils/pull/38

postparse: improve "file:line: error message" reporting

For some errors detected during the post-parse stage,
we reported the last line of the main config file,
when we meant to report the file and line
where the resource definition can be found.

Also reset the line, not only the config file name
when parsing the argument to --config-to-test.
Re-use "include_file()" for that instead of open-coding it.

We could potentially even re-use "include_stmt()" here
to allow globbing in --config-to-test.

Prepare 9.27.0

Signed-off-by: Roland Kammerer <roland.kammerer@linbit.com>

Prepare 9.27.0-rc.1

Signed-off-by: Roland Kammerer <roland.kammerer@linbit.com>

drbdmeta: Dump and restor the members field

In a cluster with an even number of diskful nodes, a partition having
exactly half of the nodes with backing disks can keep quorum when it
had contact to the majority of the diskless nodes at the moment when
diskful node count dropped to 50%.

For DRBD to restore such a quorum after reboot, it got a new field in
the meta-data, the "members" field. It contains the node masks of the
visible nodes before the node restart.

This patch adds support for dumping and restoring the members field
from the meta-data.

tests: sanitize environment

Tests did not execute successfully if for example the TZ was set to a
time zone that produces a '-' instead of an '+' in the output (e.g.,
users in the US). Fix that by setting LC_ALL and friends. UTC produces a
"+00:00" so we don't need to change the rest.

adjust,v9: Improve adjust for diskless primaries

When drbd.conf changes how a diskless node reaches nodes holding
the data, applying the changes might be nontrivial.

Consider a diskless primary, having one peer with an UpToDate
disk. One might remove the connection between the diskless node and
that node with backing disk, and add another connection to another
diskful node at the same time. That is a valid change when the two
diskful nodes have a connection.

So far, `drbdadm adjust` failed to apply such a change since it
tried to remove the connection first, and add the other one after that.

Fixing that by building in the capability that `drbdadm adjust`
recovers from the first failure by retrying it after new connections
in the resource got added and established.

drbdadm,v9: replace some calloc() with checked_calloc()

Reducing the number of open coded checks calloc()s return value.

Prepare 9.26.0

Signed-off-by: Roland Kammerer <roland.kammerer@linbit.com>

doc: update man-pagaes

Documenting new net options load-balance-paths, rdma-rcrl-rcvbuf-size
and rdma-ctrl-sndbuf-size.

Restoring alphabetical order in some option lists.

Prepare 9.26.0-rc.2

Signed-off-by: Roland Kammerer <roland.kammerer@linbit.com>

v9: New config options rdma-ctrls-(snd|rcv)buf-size

Small values may degrade performance. We cannot come up with a
one-size-fits-all number, so make it tunable.

new config option load-balance-paths

With this boolean setting, the user can enable a transport
implementation to establish all paths in parallel and distribute the
data packets over all available paths.

As of now, only the 'lb-tcp' transport module obeys this setting.

When the user does not select a transport module explicitly, DRBD
selects between tcp and 'lb-tcp' based on the 'load-balance-paths'
setting.

The user can explicitly configure 'transport "lb-tcp";' and
'load-balance-paths no;' which is then wire-protocol compatible with
the traditional 'tcp' transport.

Prepare 9.26.0-rc.1

Signed-off-by: Roland Kammerer <roland.kammerer@linbit.com>
build: fix Makefile for older make
Dockerfile: use maintainer LABEL
drbdsetup: support keyring options for TLS

drbdsetup: support TLS options

Allow users to enable kTLS on the transport.

drbdsetup: there may be more than one DRBD_NLA_CFG_REPLY

If the kernel gives more than one hint about why some operation has failed,
drbdsetup should show them all, not just the last one.
drbdmon: Simplify command validation
